docs.title: GitHub Workshop
docs.text:
Welcome! Use the navigation to explore each section of the workshop. Start with the Introduction, then proceed through the core concepts, components, collaboration, and exercises.

  • Introduction: What is GitHub and why use it?
  • Core Concepts: Learn the basics of GitHub and version control.
  • Components: Branches, commits, pull requests, and more.
  • Collaboration: How to work with others on GitHub.
  • Exercises: Hands-on activities to practice your skills.

Enjoy your learning journey!

docs.title: ☁️💻 GitHub = Your AI Coding Playground
docs.text:
GitHub is like the ultimate squad space for devs—powered by AI, living in the cloud, and ready to build anything. Whether you're:

  • 🧠 Dreaming up new features
  • 🐛 Squashing bugs
  • 🤝 Teaming up on code

GitHub's got your back.

Over 100 million devs worldwide are already here, building cool stuff and leveling it up together. It's like the global group chat for software—but with commits, not emojis (okay, maybe both 😎).

docs.title: ☁️💻 What Even Is GitHub?
docs.text: GitHub = your cloud-based dev HQ. It runs on Git (the OG version control tech) and makes coding with your crew super smooth. Whether you're building new features, fixing bugs, or collabing on code, GitHub is where 100M+ devs hang out and make magic happen.

docs.title: 🧠💬 Let’s Break Down the Big 5 Pillars of GitHub Enterprise:
🤖 AI — Your Smart Coding Sidekick
docs.text:
GitHub’s got AI baked in. Think:

  • ✨ Copilot = your AI pair programmer
  • 🧠 Smart pull requests & issues
  • 🔐 Auto security checks It’s like having a genius buddy who never sleeps.

docs.title: 🤝 Collaboration — Teamwork That Actually Works
docs.text:
No more messy group projects. GitHub gives you:

  • 📁 Repos
  • 🐞 Issues
  • 🔁 Pull Requests
  • 🏷️ Labels
  • 📣 Notifications So everyone from devs to PMs to ops can ship faster, together.

docs.title: ⚡ Productivity — Set It and Forget It
docs.text:
With built-in CI/CD, GitHub automates the boring stuff:

  • 🚀 Auto builds & deploys
  • 🧹 Less admin, more innovation
  • 🧘‍♀️ Devs stay in flow mode

docs.title: 🎯 Goal: Learn how GitHub helps you build cool stuff without breaking things.
🌿 Branches
docs.text:
Think of branches like alternate timelines in a video game. You can try wild ideas without messing up the main story. Mess up? No worries—just rewind or fix it.

You can create a new branch and check it out by using git in a terminal. The command would be 

git checkout -b newBranchName

docs.title: 💾 Commits
docs.text:
• Every time you hit save on your code = 💾 commit
  • It's like taking a selfie of your work—timestamped, ID'd, and credited to you.
  • You can always rewind and see what changed, when, and by who.

docs.title: 🔍 File States in Git
docs.text:
Your files go through a glow-up journey:

  • Untracked: Git's like "Who dis?"
  • Tracked: Git's watching 👀
  • Unmodified: No changes since last commit
  • Modified: You made changes, but haven't staged them
  • Staged: Ready for the spotlight (aka commit)
  • Committed: Locked in the Git vault 🔐

docs.title: 🔁 Pull Requests (PRs)
docs.text:
You've made something cool on your branch. Now you wanna merge it into the main project. So you open a Pull Request (PR) = "Hey team, check this out!"

Your crew:

  • Reviews it 🧐
  • Drops comments 💬
  • Approves it ✅
  • Merges it 🔗

docs.title: 🚀 The GitHub Flow (aka the Recipe for Dev Magic)
docs.text:
1. Branch it – Start fresh without breaking main
  2. Commit it – Save your progress
  3. Pull Request it – Ask for feedback
  4. Review it – Tweak and polish
  5. Merge it – Into main it goes
  6. Delete it – Clean up your branch closet 🧹

docs.title: 🤝 GitHub = Teamwork Playground
docs.text: GitHub isn't just for code—it's where devs squad up. You've got repos to organize your stuff, pull requests to share your changes, and now… meet the collab power duo:

docs.title: 🐛 Issues = To-Do List with Superpowers
docs.text:
Got a bug? Idea? Task? Drop it in an Issue.

You can create one from:

  • A task list ✅
  • A project note 🗒️
  • A comment 💬
  • A line of code 💻
  • Even a URL 🔗

🛠️ Add a title, describe the problem, assign it, label it, and boom—your team's on it.

docs.title: Creating an issue from a repository
docs.text:
1. On GitHub.com, navigate to the main page of the repository.
  2. Under your repository name, select Issues.
  1. Select New Issue
  2. If your repository uses issue templates, next to the type of issue you'd like to open select Get started.

If the type of issue you'd like to open isn't included in the available options, select Open a blank issue. If not using templates, skip to Step 5.

  1. In the Add a title field, enter a title for your issue.
  2. In the Add a description field, type a description of your issue.
  3. If you're a project maintainer, you can assign the issue to someone, add it to a project board, associate it with a milestone, or apply a label.
  4. When you're finished, select Submit new issue.

docs.title: 💬 Discussions = Dev Group Chat Vibes
docs.text:
Not everything's about code. Sometimes you just wanna talk it out.

Use Discussions for:

  • Q&A 🙋
  • Ideas 💡
  • Announcements 📣
  • Polls 🗳️
  • Show & Tell 🙌
  • General chat 🧃

Set it up in your repo settings, pick a category, and start the convo.

docs.title: Enabling a discussion in your repository
docs.text:
🛠️ Who Can Flip the Switch?

  • If you own the repo or have Write access, you've got the power to turn on GitHub Discussions—whether your repo is public or private.
  • 👀 Visibility? It matches the repo. No surprises.

docs.title: 👋 First Time Setup = Welcome Vibes
docs.text:
When you enable Discussions for the first time, GitHub's like: "Wanna drop a welcome post?"

You can customize it to set the tone for your community—friendly, focused, or full-on fun.

  1. On GitHub.com, navigate to the main page of the repository.

  2. Under your repository name, select Settings.

  1. Scroll down to the Features section and under Discussions, select Setup discussions.

  1. Under Start a new discussion, edit the template to align with the resources and tone you want to set for your community.

  2. Select Start discussion.

docs.title: 💬 Start a New Discussion Like a Pro
docs.text:
If you can see the repo, you can start the chat. That's right—any logged-in user with access can kick off a discussion.

👥 For orgs? Same deal. If you can view the source repo, you're in.

So go ahead—spark that convo, drop that idea, or ask that burning question. GitHub's got your back. 💡🔥

  1. On GitHub.com, navigate to the main page of the repository or organization where you want to start a discussion.

  2. Under your repository or organization name, select Discussions.

  1. On the right side of the page, select New discussion.

  2. Select a discussion category by selecting Get started. All discussions must be created in a category. For repository discussions, people with maintain or admin permissions to the repository define the categories for discussions in that repository.

docs.title: 🗂️ Categories = Organized Chaos (But Make It Cute)
docs.text:
Every Discussion category needs: - A unique name 🏷️ - A matching emoji 😎 - A clear description so people know what's up 🧠

Why? So convos don't get messy. You'll know what's a Q&A, what's an idea, and what's just general chat.

🧩 Categories = Filters for the vibe. Customizable. Sortable. Totally your style.

  1. Under Discussion title enter a title for your discussion, and under Write enter the body of your discussion.

docs.title: 🧪 GitHub = Safe Space to Build & Break
docs.text: With branches, commits, PRs, issues, and discussions, you can test, talk, tweak, and ship—without breaking main.

docs.title: 🧭 Exercise: GitHub Guided Tour
docs.text:
🎮 What's the Mission? You're about to flex your GitHub skills by completing a series of mini-challenges.

Think of it like a level-up quest for: - 🔀 Create a branch - 📄 Commit a file - 🔁 Open a pull request - ✅ Merge that pull request

docs.title: 🚀 How to Start
docs.text:
Hit the "Start the exercise on GitHub" button. You'll be dropped into a public template repo with your challenge path ready to go.

It's hands-on, it's guided, and it's all about mastering the GitHub flow like a boss. 💪

docs.title: What's GitHub Codespaces?
docs.text: It's your dev setup in the cloud—no installs, no drama. Just log in, code, and ship from anywhere with Wi-Fi.

docs.title: ⚙️ What's Inside?
docs.text:
• Fully loaded dev environment 🔧
  • Supports all your fave languages & tools 🧪
  • Runs in a container = clean, fast, and isolated
  • Totally customizable for your project vibe 🎨

docs.title: 🔁 Codespace Life Cycle
docs.text:
1. Create it – Boom, workspace ready
  2. Pause it – Step away, no worries
  3. Reconnect – Pick up right where you left off
  4. Delete it – When you're done, clean it up 🧹 Your changes? Safe and sound the whole time.

docs.title: 🚀 How to Create a Codespace
docs.text:
You've got 4 ways to spin up a Codespace:

  • From a template – Starting fresh? Use a GitHub template repo 🆕
  • From a branch – Working on a new feature? Branch it out 🌿
  • From a pull request – Wanna test WIP code? Dive right in 🔍
  • From a commit – Debugging history? Time travel to that commit 🕵️‍♀️

docs.title: 💡 Use It Your Way
docs.text:
• Just testing? Use it temporarily 🧪
  • Long-term feature work? Keep it running 🛠️
  • Multiple ideas? You can create more than one Codespace per repo or branch (but there's a limit, so clean up when needed 🧹)

docs.title: 🔁 Pro Tips for Workflow
docs.text:
• New Codespace every time? Push your changes often so nothing gets lost 💾
  • Long-running Codespace? Pull the latest from main before you start 🔄
  • Starting a new project? Use a template, then publish it later 📦

docs.title: ⚡ Speed Boost
docs.text: Repo admins can enable prebuilds to make Codespace creation even faster ⚙️💨

docs.title: 🛠️ Codespace Creation = 4-Step Magic
docs.text:
When you spin up a Codespace, here's what goes down:

  • 🖥️ VM + Storage → Your cloud workspace gets its own space
  • 📦 Container → Dev tools + languages packed in
  • 🔌 Connection → You link up from VS Code, browser, or CLI
  • ⚙️ Post-setup → Your custom config kicks in

docs.title: 💾 Saving Your Work
docs.text:
• Web? AutoSave = ON by default
  • VS Code? You gotta turn AutoSave ON manually
  • Work is saved in the cloud ☁️
  • Close it? No prob. Come back later and pick up where you left off
  • But if you delete the Codespace = 💥 it's gone unless you pushed to GitHub

docs.title: 🔁 Reopen, Resume, Repeat
docs.text:
• Open your Codespace from GitHub, VS Code, JetBrains, or CLI
  • Go to https://github.com/codespaces → pick your repo → resume your session
  • You can even hit the . key in a repo to launch it fast ⚡

docs.title: ⏱️Timeouts & Disconnects
docs.text:
• Inactive for 30 mins? Codespace sleeps 😴
  • Lost internet? No panic—your unsaved changes are still there
  • Reconnect and you're back in action 💪
  • Pro tip: Commit + push often if your Wi-Fi's wobbly

docs.title: 🛑 Stop, Restart, or Rebuild
docs.text:
• Stop = saves your work, cuts CPU costs
  • Restart = apply changes like new machine type
  • Rebuild = refresh your dev container (cache helps speed it up)
  • Full rebuild = clears cache, starts fresh
  • Only stuff in /workspaces survives a rebuild

docs.title: 🧹 Delete When Done
docs.text:
• Pushed your changes? Safe to delete
  • Unpushed commits? GitHub will warn you
  • You can export changes to a new branch before deleting
  • Inactive Codespaces auto-delete after 30 days (or sooner if you set it)

docs.title: 🧭 Exercise: Create your first codespace and push code
docs.text:
🎮 What's the Mission?

You're about to flex your GitHub skills by completing a series of mini-challenges.

Think of it like a level-up quest for:

  • 🚀 Start a Codespace – Launch your cloud dev zone
  • 📤 Push code – Send your updates to the repo
  • 🛠️ Add .devcontainer.json – Customize your setup
  • 🎨 Add customizations – Make it your dev vibe
  • ⚡ Run code on creation – Auto-execute setup magic
  • 🧩 Enable a dotfile – Personalize your environment
  • 📁 Add dotfile to repo + run – Lock in your custom config

docs.text:
Hit the "Start the exercise" button. You'll be dropped into a public template repo with your challenge path ready to go.

It's hands-on, it's guided, and it's all about mastering Codespaces like a boss. 💪

docs.title: 💡 What Is GitHub Copilot?
docs.text: GitHub Copilot is an AI pair programmer that helps you write better code faster. Whether you're a new developer learning to code, a student working on homework, or a professional developer, GitHub Copilot can help you complete your work faster while teaching you new skills.

docs.title: ✨ What Are Inline Suggestions?
docs.text:
Inline suggestions are AI-powered code completions that appear as you type. They help you:

  • Write code faster
  • Learn new coding patterns
  • Discover alternative approaches
  • Stay focused on your logic

docs.title: 🎛️ Command Palette = Your Dev Shortcut Bar
docs.text:
The Command Palette is your all-access pass to Copilot's features:

  • /fix - Let Copilot fix your code
  • /explain - Get a breakdown of how your code works
  • /tests - Generate unit tests automatically
  • And many more!

docs.title: 💬 Inline Chat = Talk to Copilot in your code
docs.text:
Copilot Chat is like having a smart coding buddy right in your editor:

  • Ask questions about your code
  • Get explanations of complex functions
  • Get help with debugging
  • Brainstorm solutions to problems

docs.title: ✍️ Comments → Code
docs.text:
Turn your thoughts into working code:

  • Write natural language comments
  • Describe what you want to achieve
  • Let Copilot suggest the implementation
  • Review and refine the suggestions

docs.title: 🔄 Multiple Suggestions = Pick Your Flavor
docs.text:
Don't like the first suggestion? No problem:

  • Get multiple code options
  • Choose what fits best
  • Mix and match ideas
  • Learn different approaches

docs.title: 🧠 Explanations = Code Decoder Mode
docs.text:
Need to understand some code? Copilot can help:

  • Get line-by-line explanations
  • Understand the logic flow
  • Learn best practices
  • Decode complex algorithms

docs.title: 🧪 Auto Test Generation = QA on Autopilot
docs.text:
Write tests faster with Copilot:

  • Generate test cases
  • Cover edge cases
  • Test different scenarios
  • Ensure code quality

docs.title: 🧭 Exercise: Hello Copilot! 🤖
docs.text:
🎮 What's the Mission?

You're about to flex your GitHub Copilot skills by completing a series of mini-challenges.

Think of it like a level-up quest for:

  • 🚀 Get a project intro from Copilot Chat
  • Use Copilot to help remember a terminal command 🙋
  • Use Copilot to fix our registration bug 🐛
  • Let Copilot generate sample data 📋
  • Activity: Use Copilot to describe our work 💬
  • Use Copilot to add a new feature! 🚀
  • Use Agent mode to add functional "unregister" buttons
  • Use Agent mode to change the database! 🧑‍🚀
  • Summarize and review a PR with Copilot

It's hands-on, it's guided, and it's all about mastering GitHub Copilot like a boss. 💪

docs.title: Code Scanning
docs.text: (Your content for code scanning goes here.)

docs.title: 🕵️‍♀️ What's Code Scanning?
docs.text: It's like a security scanner for your code. GitHub uses CodeQL to sniff out bugs 🐛 and vulnerabilities 🔓 in your repo. - ✅ Works on public repos - 🔐 Also works on private org repos (if GitHub Advanced Security is enabled) - 🚨 Alerts show up in the Security tab - 🧹 Fix the code → alert disappears

docs.title: 🔍 Why It's a Big Deal
docs.text:
• Finds problems early = less chaos later
  • Helps you triage + prioritize fixes
  • Stops new bugs before they sneak in
  • You can schedule scans or trigger them on events like pushes

docs.title: 🧠 What's CodeQL?
docs.text:
CodeQL = GitHub's brainy code detective 🧠🔍 It treats code like data and runs smart queries to find issues.

You can set it up 3 ways:

  1. Default setup – Fast + easy, runs as a GitHub Action
  2. Advanced setup – Full control with a custom workflow
  3. External CI – Run CodeQL CLI elsewhere, upload results to GitHub

docs.title: 🧬 Supported Languages
docs.text:
CodeQL works with both compiled + interpreted languages:

  • C / C++
  • C#
  • Go
  • Java / Kotlin
  • JavaScript / TypeScript
  • Python
  • Ruby
  • Swift

docs.title: Enable CodeQL in your repository with the Default Setup
docs.text:
If you have write permissions to a repository, you can set up or configure code scanning for that repository.

Follow these steps to set up code scanning using the CodeQL GitHub Actions workflow:

  1. On GitHub.com, navigate to the repository's main page.

  2. Under your repository name, select Security.

  1. Select Set up code scanning. If this option isn't available, ask an organization owner or repository administrator to enable GitHub Advanced Security.

  1. In the Set up drop-down, select Default.

  2. Review the default options. If needed, select the Edit button in the bottom left corner of the new window to customize how CodeQL runs.

The on:pull_request and on:push triggers are the default for code scanning are each useful for different purposes.

  1. Select Enable CodeQL once you're ready to turn on code scanning.

In the default CodeQL analysis workflow, code scanning is configured to analyze your code each time you either push a change to any protected branches or raise a pull request against the default branch. Once the push is made, code scanning runs automatically.

docs.title: 📦 Repositories 101 — The Cloud Locker for Your Code
🧠 What's a Repo?
docs.text:
A repository (aka "repo") is your project's digital HQ. It holds:

  • All your files 🗂️
  • Every version of those files 🔁
  • A full history of who did what and when 🕵️‍♀️
  • Tools to collab with your crew 🤝 It's like Google Drive for code—but way smarter.

docs.title: 🚀 How to Create a Repo (No Stress)
docs.text:
1. Go to GitHub.com

  2. Click the ➕ in the top-right → hit New repository

  1. Pick who owns it (you or your org)

  1. Name it, describe it (optional but ✨vibes✨)

  1. Choose visibility:
  2. 🌍 Public = anyone can see it

  3. 🔒 Private = just you + your squad

  4. Hit Create repository 🎉 Boom. You've got a repo.

docs.title: 📁 Adding Files Like a Pro
docs.text:
1. Go to your repo's main page
  2. Click Add file → Create new file or upload one
  1. Name your file (add folders with / if needed)
  2. Type your content
  3. Hit Preview to check it
  1. Write a short commit message (like "added README")
  1. Choose to commit to the main branch or make a new one
  1. Click Commit changes or Propose changes Congrats—you just made your first file and commit! 🥳

docs.title: 🧩 Gists, Wikis & GitHub Pages — Bonus Tools
✂️ Gists = Mini Repos for Code Snippets
docs.text:
• Share quick code bits
  • Public = searchable
  • Secret = shareable but not listed
  • Still full Git repos you can fork & clone

docs.title: 📚 Wikis = Long-Form Docs for Your Project
docs.text:
• Great for tutorials, guides, deep dives
  • Lives inside your repo
  • Private repo = private wiki

docs.title: 🌐 GitHub Pages = Turn Your Repo into a Website
docs.text: GitHub Pages = your mini website builder powered by your repo. Wanna show off your project, your team, or yourself? This is how.

docs.title: 🧱 How It Works:
docs.text:
• Drop your HTML, CSS, and JavaScript into a repo
  • GitHub turns it into a live website
  • Optional: Run it through a build process for extra magic ✨
  • Push changes → Site updates. Just like that.

docs.title: 🚀 Why It's Cool:
docs.text:
• No servers to manage
  • No extra tools needed
  • Just code → publish → done
  • Great for portfolios, docs, or project hubs

  • 👀 Visibility? It matches the repo. No surprises.

docs.title: 👋 First Time Setup = Welcome Vibes
docs.text:
When you enable Discussions for the first time, GitHub's like: "Wanna drop a welcome post?"

You can customize it to set the tone for your community—friendly, focused, or full-on fun.

  1. On GitHub.com, navigate to the main page of the repository.

  2. Under your repository name, select Settings.

  1. Scroll down to the Features section and under Discussions, select Setup discussions.

  1. Under Start a new discussion, edit the template to align with the resources and tone you want to set for your community.

  2. Select Start discussion.

docs.title: 💬 Start a New Discussion Like a Pro
docs.text:
If you can see the repo, you can start the chat. That's right—any logged-in user with access can kick off a discussion.

👥 For orgs? Same deal. If you can view the source repo, you're in.

So go ahead—spark that convo, drop that idea, or ask that burning question. GitHub's got your back. 💡🔥

  1. On GitHub.com, navigate to the main page of the repository or organization where you want to start a discussion.

  2. Under your repository or organization name, select Discussions.

  1. On the right side of the page, select New discussion.

  2. Select a discussion category by selecting Get started. All discussions must be created in a category. For repository discussions, people with maintain or admin permissions to the repository define the categories for discussions in that repository.

docs.title: 🗂️ Categories = Organized Chaos (But Make It Cute)
docs.text:
Every Discussion category needs: - A unique name 🏷️ - A matching emoji 😎 - A clear description so people know what's up 🧠

Why? So convos don't get messy. You'll know what's a Q&A, what's an idea, and what's just general chat.

🧩 Categories = Filters for the vibe. Customizable. Sortable. Totally your style.

  1. Under Discussion title enter a title for your discussion, and under Write enter the body of your discussion.

docs.title: What's GitHub Codespaces?
docs.text: It's your dev setup in the cloud—no installs, no drama. Just log in, code, and ship from anywhere with Wi-Fi.

docs.title: ⚙️ What's Inside?
docs.text:
• Fully loaded dev environment 🔧
  • Supports all your fave languages & tools 🧪
  • Runs in a container = clean, fast, and isolated
  • Totally customizable for your project vibe 🎨

docs.title: 🔁 Codespace Life Cycle
docs.text:
1. Create it – Boom, workspace ready
  2. Pause it – Step away, no worries
  3. Reconnect – Pick up right where you left off
  4. Delete it – When you're done, clean it up 🧹 Your changes? Safe and sound the whole time.

docs.title: 🚀 How to Create a Codespace
docs.text:
You've got 4 ways to spin up a Codespace:

  • From a template – Starting fresh? Use a GitHub template repo 🆕
  • From a branch – Working on a new feature? Branch it out 🌿
  • From a pull request – Wanna test WIP code? Dive right in 🔍
  • From a commit – Debugging history? Time travel to that commit 🕵️‍♀️

docs.title: 💡 Use It Your Way
docs.text:
• Just testing? Use it temporarily 🧪
  • Long-term feature work? Keep it running 🛠️
  • Multiple ideas? You can create more than one Codespace per repo or branch (but there's a limit, so clean up when needed 🧹)

docs.title: 🔁 Pro Tips for Workflow
docs.text:
• New Codespace every time? Push your changes often so nothing gets lost 💾
  • Long-running Codespace? Pull the latest from main before you start 🔄
  • Starting a new project? Use a template, then publish it later 📦

docs.title: ⚡ Speed Boost
docs.text: Repo admins can enable prebuilds to make Codespace creation even faster ⚙️💨

docs.title: 🛠️ Codespace Creation = 4-Step Magic
docs.text:
When you spin up a Codespace, here's what goes down:

  • 🖥️ VM + Storage → Your cloud workspace gets its own space
  • 📦 Container → Dev tools + languages packed in
  • 🔌 Connection → You link up from VS Code, browser, or CLI
  • ⚙️ Post-setup → Your custom config kicks in

docs.title: 💾 Saving Your Work
docs.text:
• Web? AutoSave = ON by default
  • VS Code? You gotta turn AutoSave ON manually
  • Work is saved in the cloud ☁️
  • Close it? No prob. Come back later and pick up where you left off
  • But if you delete the Codespace = 💥 it's gone unless you pushed to GitHub

docs.title: 🔁 Reopen, Resume, Repeat
docs.text:
• Open your Codespace from GitHub, VS Code, JetBrains, or CLI
  • Go to https://github.com/codespaces → pick your repo → resume your session
  • You can even hit the . key in a repo to launch it fast ⚡

docs.title: ⏱️Timeouts & Disconnects
docs.text:
• Inactive for 30 mins? Codespace sleeps 😴
  • Lost internet? No panic—your unsaved changes are still there
  • Reconnect and you're back in action 💪
  • Pro tip: Commit + push often if your Wi-Fi's wobbly

docs.title: 🛑 Stop, Restart, or Rebuild
docs.text:
• Stop = saves your work, cuts CPU costs
  • Restart = apply changes like new machine type
  • Rebuild = refresh your dev container (cache helps speed it up)
  • Full rebuild = clears cache, starts fresh
  • Only stuff in /workspaces survives a rebuild

docs.title: 🧹 Delete When Done
docs.text:
• Pushed your changes? Safe to delete
  • Unpushed commits? GitHub will warn you
  • You can export changes to a new branch before deleting
  • Inactive Codespaces auto-delete after 30 days (or sooner if you set it)

docs.title: 💡 What Is GitHub Copilot?
docs.text: GitHub Copilot is an AI pair programmer that helps you write better code faster. Whether you're a new developer learning to code, a student working on homework, or a professional developer, GitHub Copilot can help you complete your work faster while teaching you new skills.

docs.title: ✨ What Are Inline Suggestions?
docs.text:
Inline suggestions are AI-powered code completions that appear as you type. They help you:

  • Write code faster
  • Learn new coding patterns
  • Discover alternative approaches
  • Stay focused on your logic

docs.title: 🎛️ Command Palette = Your Dev Shortcut Bar
docs.text:
The Command Palette is your all-access pass to Copilot's features:

  • /fix - Let Copilot fix your code
  • /explain - Get a breakdown of how your code works
  • /tests - Generate unit tests automatically
  • And many more!

docs.title: 💬 Inline Chat = Talk to Copilot in your code
docs.text:
Copilot Chat is like having a smart coding buddy right in your editor:

  • Ask questions about your code
  • Get explanations of complex functions
  • Get help with debugging
  • Brainstorm solutions to problems

docs.title: ✍️ Comments → Code
docs.text:
Turn your thoughts into working code:

  • Write natural language comments
  • Describe what you want to achieve
  • Let Copilot suggest the implementation
  • Review and refine the suggestions

docs.title: 🔄 Multiple Suggestions = Pick Your Flavor
docs.text:
Don't like the first suggestion? No problem:

  • Get multiple code options
  • Choose what fits best
  • Mix and match ideas
  • Learn different approaches

docs.title: 🧠 Explanations = Code Decoder Mode
docs.text:
Need to understand some code? Copilot can help:

  • Get line-by-line explanations
  • Understand the logic flow
  • Learn best practices
  • Decode complex algorithms

docs.title: 🧪 Auto Test Generation = QA on Autopilot
docs.text:
Write tests faster with Copilot:

  • Generate test cases
  • Cover edge cases
  • Test different scenarios
  • Ensure code quality

docs.title: 🕵️‍♀️ What's Code Scanning?
docs.text: It's like a security scanner for your code. GitHub uses CodeQL to sniff out bugs 🐛 and vulnerabilities 🔓 in your repo. - ✅ Works on public repos - 🔐 Also works on private org repos (if GitHub Advanced Security is enabled) - 🚨 Alerts show up in the Security tab - 🧹 Fix the code → alert disappears

docs.title: 🔍 Why It's a Big Deal
docs.text:
• Finds problems early = less chaos later
  • Helps you triage + prioritize fixes
  • Stops new bugs before they sneak in
  • You can schedule scans or trigger them on events like pushes

docs.title: 🧠 What's CodeQL?
docs.text:
CodeQL = GitHub's brainy code detective 🧠🔍 It treats code like data and runs smart queries to find issues.

You can set it up 3 ways:

  1. Default setup – Fast + easy, runs as a GitHub Action
  2. Advanced setup – Full control with a custom workflow
  3. External CI – Run CodeQL CLI elsewhere, upload results to GitHub

docs.title: 🧬 Supported Languages
docs.text:
CodeQL works with both compiled + interpreted languages:

  • C / C++
  • C#
  • Go
  • Java / Kotlin
  • JavaScript / TypeScript
  • Python
  • Ruby
  • Swift

docs.title: Enable CodeQL in your repository with the Default Setup
docs.text:
If you have write permissions to a repository, you can set up or configure code scanning for that repository.

Follow these steps to set up code scanning using the CodeQL GitHub Actions workflow:

  1. On GitHub.com, navigate to the repository's main page.

  2. Under your repository name, select Security.

  1. Select Set up code scanning. If this option isn't available, ask an organization owner or repository administrator to enable GitHub Advanced Security.

  1. In the Set up drop-down, select Default.

  2. Review the default options. If needed, select the Edit button in the bottom left corner of the new window to customize how CodeQL runs.

The on:pull_request and on:push triggers are the default for code scanning are each useful for different purposes.

  1. Select Enable CodeQL once you're ready to turn on code scanning.

In the default CodeQL analysis workflow, code scanning is configured to analyze your code each time you either push a change to any protected branches or raise a pull request against the default branch. Once the push is made, code scanning runs automatically.
